metadata.title: The molecular basis for Pompe disease 3 revealed by the structure of human acid α-glucosidase 4 5

abstract.text: Pompe disease results from a defect in human acid α-glucosidase (GAA), a lysosomal enzyme 17 that cleaves terminal α1-4 and α1-6 glucose from glycogen. In Pompe disease (also known as 18 Glycogen Storage Disorder type II), the accumulation of undegraded glycogen in lysosomes 19 leads to cellular dysfunction, primarily in muscle and heart tissues. Pompe disease is an active 20 candidate of clinical research, with pharmacological chaperone therapy tested and enzyme 21 replacement therapy approved. Despite production of large amounts of recombinant GAA 22 annually, the structure of GAA has not been reported until now. Here, we describe the first 23 structure of GAA, at 1.7Å resolution. Three structures of GAA complexes reveal the molecular 24 basis for the hundreds of mutations that lead to Pompe disease and for pharmacological 25 chaperoning in the protein. The GAA structure reveals a surprising second sugar-binding site 26

body_text.text: Introduction encompasses residues 347-726 and has the characteristic (β/α) 8 topology found in the catalytic 109 domain of family 31 glycoside hydrolases. C-terminal to the catalytic (β/α) 8 domain, the GAA 110 structure contains two additional β-sandwich domains. Domain C1 spans residues 727-820 and 111 is composed of seven antiparallel β-strands in 5-and 2-stranded β-sheets. The C2 domain has 112 a β-sandwich topology and is composed of 10 β-strands in two 5-stranded β-sheets, with two 113 small α-helices inserted ( Fig. 1 and Fig. 1 supplement B) . and the surface-exposed C938 and C952 in the C2 domain (Fig. 1) .

Proteolytic treatment prior to crystallization mimics proteolytic maturation in the late endosome 124 and lysosome. Electron density is missing for loops 116-122, 199-205, and 782-792. 125 Presumably, the flexible loops in the intact protein limited the resolution of the intact GAA 126 crystals. After cleavage of the three loops, the remaining fragments remain associated by non- Active site and ligand binding 136 The active site of GAA is an acidic pocket at the base of a conical funnel lined by hydrophobic 137 residues in the (β/α) 8 barrel catalytic domain (Fig. 1, Fig. 2, and Fig. 2 supplement A) . The To better understand substrate recognition in GAA, we determined complexes of the enzyme 155 with isomaltose and maltotriose (di-and tri-saccharide fragments of glycogen) at 2.0 and 1.9Å 156 resolution, respectively. The structures show glucose present in the active site with no clear proximity of active site residues D282, M519, and R600, β-linked substituents beyond a 161 hydroxyl are sterically blocked, and thus we conclude that the β-glucose appears in the active 162 site after cleavage of α-linked substrate and subsequent ring opening of the α-glucose product. 163 Residues D404, D616, and H674 confer glucose substrate specificity by hydrogen bonding to 164 hydroxyls on the ligand (Fig. 2) . Hydrophobic residues W376, L405, I441, W481, W516, M519, 165 W613 and F649 contribute to active site architecture and substrate binding. We also determined the complex of GAA bound to 1-deoxynojirimycin (DNJ) (Fig. 2) shallow cleft in the N1 domain 34Å away from the active site ( Fig. 3 and Fig. 3 supplement A) . 176 In the second site, the non-reducing ends of isomaltose and maltotriose bind identically, with 177 hydrogen bonds between the glucose hydroxyls and the side chain of D91 and the main chain per side chain atom possessing less than 2 Å 2 , between 2-9 Å 2 , and above 9 were considered 249 buried, partially buried or exposed respectively. FIGREF0.text: structure reveals extensive post-translational modifications of the polypeptide. The N-116 linked glycosylation sites show clear electron density at six of the seven reported sites. The 13 117 cysteine residues form five disulfide bonds, three in domain N1 (82-109, 92-108, and 103-127) 118 and two in the catalytic domain (533-558 and 647-655). The disulfide arrangement in N1 119 matches the 1-5, 2-4 and 3-6 connectivity found in other P-type trefoil domains (Sim et al., 2008, 120 Wright et al., 1997). Three remaining cysteines are unpaired, including C374 near the active site121

FIGREF1.text: 127 covalent interactions and a disulfide bond in N1 and by non-covalent interactions in domains N2 128 and C1. Extensive surface area remains buried in the mature GAA: 1105 Å 2 (and the C103-6 135

FIGREF2.text: 138 funnel and active site are formed by loops at the C-terminal ends of each of the eight β-strands 139 forming the β-barrel. Additionally, loop 281-286 from the N2 domain contributes to substrate 140 recognition in the active site (Fig. 2 supplement A). Thirteen residues (D282, W376, D404, 141 L405, I441, W481, W516, D518, M519, R600, D616, W618, F649, L650, H674) define the 142 active site within 5Å of the glucose ligand (Fig. 2). 143 144 GAA uses a double-displacement reaction mechanism found in family 31 glycoside hydrolases, 145 leading to overall retention of the anomeric configuration of the α-glucoside substrate (Bourne 146 and Henrissat, 2001, Koshland, 1953). The nucleophile D518 falls 3.1Å from the C1 position of 147 glucose, in position to make a nucleophilic attack on the carbon. The acid/base D616 falls on 148 the opposite side of the cleaved glycosidic linkage, 2.9Å from the O1 of the ligand, in position to 149protonate the leaving group during catalysis(Fig. 2). Fitting the pH-dependence curve for GAA 150 activity (Fig. 2 supplement B) yields two pKa values (3.6 and 5.3), which we interpret as the 151 pKa's for D518 and D616 respectively, consistent with the double-

FIGREF4.text: investigated for the treatment of Pompe disease. DNJ, a glucose 169 analog, binds in the active site and acts as a competitive inhibitor of GAA. A global fit of 170 substrate vs. inhibitor vs. velocity data leads to a K i for DGJ of 150 +/-8 nM (Fig. 2 supplement 171 C).

FIGREF5.text: the maltotriose and isomaltose structures reveal a second sugar binding site, a 175

FIGREF6.text: 178of G123, W126 and C127 (Fig. 3 and Fig. 3 supplement A). In the second site, the penultimate179 sugars of the two substrate fragments bind differently, where the maltotriose stacks directly over 180 W126 and the isomaltose shifts closer to the main chain of I98. The second binding site falls 181 close to a loop that is removed during proteolytic maturation of GAA, which might explain how 182 glycogen affinity and enzymatic activity increase in mature GAA.

FIGREF7.text: family 31 glycoside hydrolases are multi-domain proteins, but the functions of 185 the non-catalytic domains are poorly understood. The identification of a second carbohydrate-8 binding site in GAA suggests a functional role for the P-type trefoil domain in domain N1 as a 187 carbohydrate-binding module (CBM). The presence of a CBM in the N-terminal domain explains 188 the observation that the D91N variant of GAA binds carbohydrate less effectively and exhibits 189 faster electrophoretic mobility on a starch gel (Martiniuk et al., 1990).

FIGREF8.text: the two ligand-binding sites on GAA 192 The second binding site offers a potential explanation of for the observation that mature GAA 193 shows increased enzymatic activity for larger substrates. To better understand the interaction of 194 GAA with glycogen, we modeled the GAA:glycogen interaction, guided by the two ligand-binding 195 sites seen crystallographically (Figure 4). We computationally minimized a glycogen fragment 196 containing 26 glucose residues with one branch point, and then manually docked the glycogen 197 model into the GAA structure. The glycogen model fits into the two GAA binding sites with only 198 minor adjustments of two dihedrals. The model immediately suggests a mechanism of action of 199 GAA on glycogen, where the cleavage of the glycogen in the active site is followed by release of 200 product from the active site coincident with glycogen binding in the second site, leading to a 201 high effective concentration of glycogen at all stages. 202 203 Pompe disease mutations 204 More than 550 polymorphisms in human GAA have been identified (Kroos et al., 2012), and 205 over 450 mutations are thought to be pathogenic for Pompe disease (

FIGREF13.text: Overall Structure of GAA. (A) GAA cleaves terminal α1-4-and α1-6-815 linked glucose from glycogen polymers. (B) Electrostatic surface potential with the reaction 816 product α-glucose (yellow) bound to the active site. (C-D) Ribbon diagram of GAA colored by 817 domain, with N-linked glycans shown in grey and glucose (yellow) bound to the active site. 818 Dotted lines indicate residues missing in electron density. (E) Schematic of the GAA polypeptide 819 colored by domain showing the location of disulfide bonds, N-linked glycans and free cysteines.

(A-B) Electron 824 density contoured at 1.0σ. (C) The pharmacological chaperone DNJ bound to the active site. (D) 825 Comparison of the binding interaction between the heterocyclic atom of the ligand and 826 nucleophile. (E) Proposed α-retaining reaction mechanism. GAA contains a second substrate binding site. (A) Structure of GAA with glucose 829 (yellow) bound to the active site and maltotriose (yellow) bound to the N-terminal domain. (B) 830 Surface representation of the CBM in the N-terminal domain with maltotriose bound (yellow).

The 862 catalytic domain (green) and the N2 domain (cyan) are shown. A collection of hydrophobic and Supplement B. pH profile of GAA activity. Profile shows maximal activity Supplement C. Inhibition of GAA by glucose and DNJ. (A) Inhibition of GAA by 871 glucose, using a global fit to equation 1, the Michaelis-Menten equation for a competitive 872 inhibitor. (B-C) Inhibition of GAA by DNJ. Data were initially fit using equation 1, then refit using 873 the Morrison equation (Equation 2) because DNJ is a tight-binding inhibitor. Error bars show the 874 standard deviation of two replicates. Supplement D. Both α and β anomers of glucose bind to the active site. Supplement A. Most pathological point mutations occur in buried residues. (A) 888 The accessible surface area per side chain atom was calculated and residues plotted in 889 ascending order. (B) Using the same residue order as panel A, point mutations causing Pompe 890 disease were plotted. Mutations affecting the active site are shown in red.

TABREF0.text: . Of the Pompe disease-associated mutations, 245 are missense mutations leading to substitutions of single amino acids. To better understand genotype-phenotype correlations in Pompe disease, we mapped the 245 reported missense mutations onto the structure (Fig. 1 supplement B). 64% of all pathological point mutations map to the catalytic domain, 22% map to the N2 domain, and the remaining 14% map to the other three domains. Changes in buried residues are found more often than in surface residues: 23% of all buried residues have a Pompe disease-associated mutation, while only 5% of surface residues do (Fig. 4 supplement A). Because missense mutations in buried residues are most common, Pompe disease is primarily a disorder of protein Human GAA was expressed in Chinese hamster ovary cells(Moreland et al., 2005). GAA (in 50mM sodium phosphate pH 6.2, 4% mannitol and 0.01% Tween 80) was incubated with proteinase K at a molar ratio of 280:1 at 37˚C for 20 hours. The protease was removed by size exclusion chromatography on a Superdex 75 10/300 GL column (GE) equilibrated with 50mM sodium phosphate pH 6.2 and 250mM NaCl.Protease-treated GAA was concentrated to 7-20mg/ml in 20mM Bis-Tris, pH 6. The protein was mixed 1:1 to 1:3 with crystallization solution containing 100mM sodium HEPES, pH 7.5, 2% (v/v) PEG 400 and 2M ammonium sulfate. Crystals took two to six months to grow in sitting drop vapor diffusion experiments. Crystals were transferred into harvest buffer (100mM sodium HEPES, pH 7.5, 3% (v/v) PEG 400, and 2.2M ammonium sulfate) and flash cooled in harvest buffer with 20% glycerol added. To form complexes, crystals were soaked in harvest buffer supplemented with ligand, either 2mM DNJ for 12 hours, 10% (w/v) isomaltose for 2-10 minutes, or 10% (w/v) maltotriose for 2-10 minutes. Prior to cooling, the ligand soaks were shifted to harvest buffer containing 2mM DNJ and 20% glycerol or harvest buffer containing 20% saccharide. X-ray diffraction data were collected on beam line 14-1 of Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Lightsource at 1.1808Å wavelength. Diffraction data were indexed and integrated using iMosflm, and scaled and reduced in space group P2 1 2 1 2 1 using Aimless (Evans andMurshudov, 2013) and Ctruncate (Stein and Ballard, 2009). Molecular replacement was performed in AMoRe (Navaza, 1994) from the CCP4 suite (Cowtan et al., 2011) using the 44% identical N-terminal subunit of human maltase-glucoamylase (PDB code 2QLY) (Sim et al., 2008), resulting in an initial R-factor of 46%. Subsequent building and refinement was performed in Coot (Emsley and Cowtan, 2004) and Refmac5 (Murshudov et al., 2011), respectively. Figures were constructed in Pymol (Schrödinger, 2015) and PovScript (Fenn et al., Accessible surface area per residue was calculated using Areaimol in CCP4 (Cowtan et al., 2011) and then ported to Excel for further analysis.
